The gun for sale here is a German-made Walther P99, not the American-made copy Smith & Wesson SW99 copy.

Additional 15-round magazines are available from CDNN for about $35 each (S&W / Magnum Research) and from Cheaper Than Dirt for about $45 each (Walther)

CDNN is a great company that I've been doing business with for over 15 years, and is always the first place I look for when I need magazines.

Date code on frame is KI, meaning this gun was manufactured in 1998, about a year or two after the P99 was first introduced.

This has the "AS" (anti-stress) trigger, although I don't think it was called that at the time.  It has a knob on the slide to de-cock the internal striker, so the first shot is double-action, with subsequent shots being single-action.  If you're familiar with the classic SIG pistols (P22x series), then you have an idea of how this works; except that the P99 has an internal-striker instead of an external-hammer.


-- caveats --

This is one of the early Walther P99s, with a proprietary accessory rail.  Lights and lasers designed for the standard [M-1913 "Picatinny" rail will not fit.  I don't know if lights for the Walther rail are available. 

But it doesn't matter, because the previous owner (a co-worker of mine) removed material from the frame with a Dremel tool so he could fit some cheap Airsoft laser on the gun, but he did not do a very good job.  The damage does not affect functioning of the gun, and is in a small area, but it is noticeable.  Some fine-grit sandpaper and patience may remove the tool marks.  'Tis a pity, because in my opinion the first-generation P99 was the most aesthetically pleasing version of the P99.





Also, a lot of users reported that the "ski hump" or "ski jump" in the trigger guard pinched their fingers.  While I haven't had this problem, the magazine release lever does rub on my finger when firing, causing discomfort.  Some fine-grit sandpaper and some patience may fix this problem.  Perhaps having smaller fingers than I do -- I have big hands -- may also help.  Personally, I believe a lot of people who experienced discomfort with their trigger finger mis-diagnosed the cause. 




That being said, if I wasn't so heavily invested in Glock -- [i]i.e.[/i], I already have sunken costs in holsters for my Glock, a back-up Glock for my Glock, lots of Glock magazines, and time spent learning to shoot the Glock over the past 20+ years -- this would probably be my carry gun (if I could mitigate the problem with my finger rubbing against the magazine release lever).  

The ergonomics of the Walther P99 are [i]much[/i] better than Glock's, and I've really come to appreciate why some people like the double-action/de-docker SIG-like trigger mechanism.

In 2004, Walther re-designed the P99.  They replaced the proprietary rail with a standard M-1913 "Picatinny" rail, and removed the "ski hump" from the trigger guard in response to user complaints.
